5.snippet: Oracle's cloud infrastructure expertise and NVIDIA's AI platform are transforming financial institutions through AI adoption at unprecedented scale.

6.title: Mitel MiCollab, Oracle WebLogic Server vulnerabilities exploited by attackers
6.snippet: Mitel MiCollab is a popular enterprise collaboration suite. CVE-2024-41713 and CVE-2024-55550 are both path traversal vulnerabilities.
6.content:
CISA has added Mitel MiCollab (CVE-2024-41713, CVE-2024-55550) and Oracle WebLogic Server (CVE-2020-2883) vulnerabilities to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog.

The Mitel MiCollab vulnerabilities exploited

Mitel MiCollab is a popular enterprise collaboration suite.

CVE-2024-41713 and CVE-2024-55550 are both path traversal vulnerabilities.

The former is exploitable without authentication, and may allow an attacker to gain access “to provisioning information including non-sensitive user and network information and perform unauthorized administrative actions on the MiCollab Server.”

The latter can only be exploited by an authenticated attacker with administrative privileges, to access specific resources and non-sensitive system information. The vulnerability does not allow file modification or privilege escalation, Mitel says.

Both vulnerabilities were reported to Mitel by watchTowr researcher Sonny Macdonald. Two months after the patch for CVE-2024-41713 had been made available, he shared details about them publicly, as well as a proof-of-concept exploit chaining them together.

CVE-2024-55550 did not have a CVE number at the time and still doesn’t have a fix, but it’s “substantially mitigated” in MiCollab 9.8 SP2 (9.8.2.12) and will be addressed by Mitel in future product updates. (Patches for older MiCollab versions are also available.)

The Oracle WebLogic Server vulnerability

CVE-2020-2883 is an “easily exploitable” vulnerability that may allow an unauthenticated attacker with network access via IIOP or T3 protocols to execute code in the context of the service account and thus to compromise / take over a vulnerable Oracle WebLogic Server.

The vulnerability, which was a bypass of a patch for a previous one (CVE-2020-2555), was fixed in April 2020.

CISA’s additional advice

By adding the three flaws to its KEV catalog, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency effectively confirms their in-the-wild exploitation and tells US federal civilian executive branch agencies that they have three weeks to remediate them. Details about the attacks are usually not shared.

The interesting thing about this latest KEV update is that CVE-2020-2883 was flagged as exploited by CISA back in May 2020, before the KEV catalog was created. It’s unknown why the agency decided to add the flaw to it now, but it’s possible they received more recent reports of attacks in the wild.

In this latest KEV update, CISA has also urged users and administrators to review threat briefs and security bulletins related to CVE-2024-0012 and CVE-2024-9474, two vulnerabilities in Palo Alto Networks firewalls that have been exploited (as zero-days) by attackers in November 2024.

7.title: Critical Mitel, Oracle flaws find active exploitation, CISA urges patching
7.snippet: Critical Mitel, Oracle flaws find active exploitation, CISA urges patching · Attackers are actively expoiting flaws in Mitel MiCollab flaws to gain unauthorized...
7.content:
Attackers are actively expoiting flaws in Mitel MiCollab flaws to gain unauthorized access to sensitive system files, the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has warned.

On Tuesday the agency added two path traversal vulnerabilities in the widely used communication platform to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of exploitation.

“These type of vulnerabilities are frequent attack vectors for malicious cyber actors and pose significant risks to the federal enterprise,” CISA said in an advisory that also mentioned a critical Oracle flaw, first reported in 2022, which likely now has N-day exploits.

8.title: How to strengthen supply chain with Oracle
8.snippet: Companies working in very diverse sectors share their experiences working with PwC to help achieve supply chain efficiencies within Oracle Cloud.
8.content:
Driving business agility with cloud-based supply chain optimization

Infrastructure breakdowns, public health crises, changing customer demands and technology breakthroughs have dramatically changed the face of supply chain management in recent years. As companies in various sectors examine their ability to manage risks and take advantage of new opportunities, many are recognizing the need to upgrade their systems and processes. New technologies offered by PwC and Oracle offer organizations advanced supply chain solutions to help them address issues across the supply chain—including challenges in master data management, order orchestration, sourcing/procurement and manufacturing/fulfillment.

No two supply chains are alike, and the challenges many organizations can face are as diverse as the organizations themselves. Some companies are discovering efficiency shortfalls in outdated systems that pose obstacles to integration and result in fragmented data. Others have identified the need to stay current with evolving data governance and regulatory requirements. With advanced supply chain management, businesses can enable the caliber of demand forecasting, inventory improvements, supplier collaboration and production scheduling they need to boost efficiency and reduce costs—no matter how complex or global their supply chain operations may be.

During an Oracle CloudWorld 2024 panel discussion, representatives of multiple companies working in very diverse sectors shared their experiences working with PwC to help achieve supply chain efficiencies within Oracle Cloud. Their experiences put a spotlight on challenges familiar to many companies struggling with the complexities of the modern-day supply chain.

9.title: Oracle exec maps data integration strategy for modern clinical trials in 2025 and beyond
9.snippet: In this Q&A, Chris Boone, Ph.D., group vice president of research services at Oracle Health & Life Sciences, takes a look at the hurdles—and possibilities—...
9.content:
From FHIR-based APIs to “hybrid data models” and blockchain-enabled audit trails, biopharma companies are exploring a range of strategies in their quest to incorporate Real World Data (RWD) into clinical trials. But technology alone won’t resolve the deeper issues at play. From bridging disparate data sources to safeguarding patient privacy under evolving regulations, sponsors face significant operational and ethical dilemmas. In this Q&A, Chris Boone, Ph.D., group vice president of research services at Oracle Health & Life Sciences, takes a look at the hurdles—and possibilities—shaping tomorrow’s clinical trial landscape.

In the Q&A below, Boone sheds light on everything from specific operational bottlenecks to the infrastructure needed for continuous, embedded clinical trials—offering concrete examples drawn from real-world collaborations and technologies. He also reveals how sponsors can incorporate genuine patient feedback without derailing trial timelines, explains the interplay of evolving data standards like FHIR and CDISC, and underscores privacy frameworks that respect patient data ownership while advancing scientific discovery. Rounding out the discussion are the key ROI metrics organizations should track to measure value from RWD initiatives and a candid look at how teams can future-proof their trials amid shifting regulatory landscapes.

To jump directly to a specific section’s detailed analysis, click on the corresponding question below:

What specific operational and regulatory barriers impede RWD integration into clinical trials, and what solutions have proven effective in overcoming these challenges?

Incorporating Real-World Data (RWD) into clinical trials can involve considerable operational and regulatory hurdles. However, innovative solutions are arising from industry collaboration and technological progress. It is essential for organizations aiming to utilize RWD effectively in clinical research to comprehend these obstacles and their validated solutions.

From an operational perspective, data quality and standardization pose significant challenges. Healthcare data comes from various sources – electronic health records, claims databases, patient registries, and wearable devices – each with its own formats and standards. The Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) has effectively tackled this issue through its Healthcare Link Initiative (https://www.cdisc.org/healthcare-link), showcasing how organizations can integrate data across platforms while preserving integrity.

Modern solutions have effectively addressed technical infrastructure challenges, particularly legacy systems and interoperability issues. For example, the FDA’s Sentinel Initiative (https://www.sentinelinitiative.org/) demonstrates how distributed networks can enable secure collaboration across multiple sites while maintaining privacy compliance. Organizations have successfully implemented FHIR-based APIs and “hybrid data models” that seamlessly integrate real-world data with traditional clinical trial data.

Resource and expertise constraints represent another significant challenge. Establishing more academic and formal training programs to educate the next generation of research scientists and leaders is necessary to address the skills gap in this emerging field effectively.

On the regulatory front, data privacy and consent requirements pose complex challenges across jurisdictions. Organizations have adopted dynamic consent management systems that empower patients to control their data-sharing preferences while ensuring compliance with diverse international privacy regulations such as GDPR and HIPAA. Advanced de-identification techniques and secure computing enclaves have been effective in safeguarding patient privacy while facilitating meaningful data sharing.

The evolving regulatory framework for RWD use in clinical trials has created uncertainty regarding the acceptance of RWD-derived evidence. Success has been achieved through early and consistent engagement with regulatory authorities during the development of Real World Evidence guidance. Organizations that proactively establish clear protocols for data quality assurance have experienced greater success in navigating these challenges.

To meet validation and reliability requirements, organizations have adopted blockchain-based audit trails that capture every touchpoint in the data lifecycle. Comprehensive quality assurance programs incorporating automated data quality checking systems and ongoing monitoring processes ensure reliability and transparency.

Organizations that have successfully integrated RWD into clinical trials typically follow a comprehensive framework that includes:

Strategic partnerships between healthcare providers and sponsors

Standardized operating procedures for data curation

Automated quality control systems

Continuous monitoring processes

Structured documentation practices

The most successful implementations adopt a phased approach, prioritizing solutions based on particular organizational challenges while progressively developing more sophisticated capabilities. This methodical strategy guarantees sustainable implementation and enables adaptation as the regulatory and technical landscape evolves.

Despite these challenges, integrating RWD into clinical trials signifies a transformative shift in generating evidence and delivering healthcare. Achieving success requires ongoing investment in data infrastructure, interoperability standards, and privacy-preserving technologies. Organizations that adopt these solutions as part of a comprehensive strategy, backed by sufficient resources and executive commitment, are best equipped to overcome the obstacles to RWD integration and fully harness its potential to advance clinical research.

Describe the technical infrastructure requirements and governance frameworks needed to implement continuous, embedded clinical trials while maintaining data integrity and compliance.

Implementing continuous, embedded clinical trials demands a sophisticated integration of technical infrastructure and governance frameworks to uphold data integrity and ensure regulatory compliance. This comprehensive strategy must balance real-time data operations with strong security measures while maintaining adherence to regulations.

Technical Infrastructure

The technical infrastructure foundation starts with a scalable data collection and integration layer. For instance, the FDA’s MyStudies platform (https://www.fda.gov/drugs/science-and-research-drugs/fdas-mystudies-application) illustrates how cloud-based architecture can support real-time data ingestion from various sources while ensuring compliance. Organizations need to implement standardized APIs and interoperability protocols, such as FHIR and HL7, to guarantee seamless data exchange across platforms. The success of this integration is evident in the Sentinel Initiative’s distributed database system (https://www.sentinelinitiative.org/), which processes healthcare data while upholding security and compliance across multiple institutions.

At the core of this infrastructure is the data storage and processing layer. Distributed database systems optimized for healthcare data must be paired with secure data lakes to manage unstructured and semi-structured data. High-performance computing resources enable complex analytics, while versioning systems preserve data lineage and ensure reproducibility. The Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) offers frameworks for standardizing these processes (https://www.cdisc.org/).

Security infrastructure is a vital element that requires end-to-end encryption for data both at rest and in transit. Strong identity and access management systems, multi-factor authentication, and network security controls protect sensitive trial data. Security information and event management (SIEM) systems provide continuous monitoring and threat detection.

The analytics and reporting layer must facilitate real-time analysis and monitoring of trial data, encompassing statistical computing environments, visualization tools, and machine learning infrastructure for pattern detection. Automated alert and notification systems guarantee a timely response to adverse events or data quality issues.

Governance Frameworks

Governance frameworks are vital for supporting compliance and maintaining data quality. Data governance frameworks should define clear ownership and stewardship roles, establish standard operating procedures for data handling, and implement comprehensive data quality management protocols. This encompasses detailed metadata management policies and data lifecycle management procedures.

Regulatory compliance frameworks should document and monitor adherence to relevant requirements, maintaining comprehensive audit trails and risk assessment protocols. Privacy and security governance frameworks must include regular impact assessments, incident response plans, and thorough data-sharing agreements to protect patient information while allowing necessary access for trial operations.

Implementation success relies significantly on effective system integration and quality control measures. Organizations must establish clear performance monitoring frameworks that track system performance metrics, data quality indicators, and compliance checks. The training and support infrastructure plays a vital role, requiring comprehensive staff training programs, technical support systems, and thorough documentation.

The integration of these technical and governance components creates a comprehensive ecosystem that facilitates efficient trial execution while supporting regulatory compliance and data integrity. Organizations must invest in continuously developing and refining these systems, adapting to changing regulatory requirements and technological advancements.

Conclusion

Success involves a balanced approach that emphasizes both technical capability and governance rigor while retaining flexibility to adapt to evolving requirements. By paying careful attention to these infrastructure and governance standards, organizations can create sustainable platforms for conducting continuous, embedded clinical trials that can advance medical research, protect patient interests, and maintain regulatory compliance.

The key is to create an integrated ecosystem that balances the needs for data integrity, regulatory compliance, and operational efficiency while enabling continuous learning and improvement in the execution of clinical trials.

How can sponsors effectively incorporate patient feedback into protocol design while preserving scientific rigor and operational efficiency?

Effectively integrating patient feedback into clinical trial protocol design while upholding scientific rigor and operational efficiency demands a well-structured approach. Recent industry initiatives illustrate how early engagement through patient advisory boards and organized feedback mechanisms can enhance protocol development.

For example, the Clinical Trials Transformation Initiative (CTTI), a public-private partnership with the FDA, developed the Patient Groups and Clinical Trials project, which offers evidence-based recommendations for involving patient groups in clinical trials (source: https://ctti-clinicaltrials.org/topics/patient-engagement/). Their framework demonstrates how early patient engagement can result in more feasible protocols and better recruitment rates.

A systematic approach to feedback collection and integration is crucial. The Patient-Focused Drug Development (PFDD) program by the FDA illustrates this through its organized collection of patient experience data to inform trial design (source: https://www.fda.gov/drugs/development-approval-process-drugs/patient-focused-drug-development-guidance). Its structured methodology for incorporating patient input has become a standard for the industry.

TransCelerate BioPharma’s Patient Protocol Engagement Toolkit (P-PET) has successfully demonstrated that it is possible to maintain scientific rigor while incorporating patient feedback. This toolkit offers standardized methods for gathering and implementing patient input, all while preserving trial integrity (source: https://www.transceleratebiopharmainc.com/patient-experience/patient-protocol/).

The Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI) has established comprehensive methodological standards for engaging patients in research. These standards demonstrate how operational efficiency can be sustained through streamlined processes and optimized resource use (source: https://www.pcori.org/research-results/about-our-research/research-methodology).

Quality management is vital for successful implementation. The European Patients’ Academy on Therapeutic Innovation (EUPATI) has developed guidelines for patient involvement in clinical trials that illustrate how maintaining clear audit trails for regulatory compliance can align with patient-centric design (source: https://eupati.eu/).

Communication is a critical element. The Drug Information Association (DIA) has documented successful case studies of sponsor-patient collaboration in protocol design, demonstrating how regular updates and ongoing dialogue with patient representatives can foster continuous engagement throughout the protocol development process (source: https://www.diaglobal.org/).

Success requires a careful balance of various perspectives. The NHS Health Research Authority’s framework for public involvement standards offers a structured method for integrating patient input while upholding scientific and operational requirements (source: https://www.hra.nhs.uk/planning-and-improving-research/best-practice/public-involvement/).

Sponsors can integrate patient perspectives into protocol design through this structured approach, resulting in more patient-centered trials while upholding scientific rigor. The documented successes of these organizations show that patient engagement in protocol design isn’t just theoretically sound – it’s practically attainable and beneficial for all stakeholders involved.

Which data standards and interoperability initiatives should life sciences organizations prioritize by 2025 to enable integrated research-care systems?

As healthcare and clinical research increasingly converge, life sciences organizations face an essential dilemma: Which data standards and interoperability efforts should be prioritized to develop integrated research-care systems? The situation is complex, yet a few key initiatives stand out as critical for achieving success in 2025.

At the core are FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) and CDISC standards, which are recognized as the gold standards for healthcare data exchange and clinical research data. These serve as universal languages that enable seamless communication between various healthcare and research systems. The most recent version, FHIR R5, offers improved support for research data elements, while the CDISC standards ensure regulatory compliance and data consistency across clinical trials.

Participating in significant initiatives like HL7 and the DARWIN EU network from the European Medicines Agency has become vital for organizations looking to enhance their data interoperability skills. The DARWIN EU network illustrates how coordinated networks can effectively generate real-world evidence from healthcare data across different countries while complying with rigorous scientific and regulatory standards.

Organizations need to focus on three key areas:

First, the integration of data standards must prioritize the alignment between research and healthcare data. This involves implementing FHIR R5 alongside established CDISC standards while consistently applying clinical terminologies (e.g., RxNorm, SNOMED CT). The FDA’s recent guidance emphasizes this approach, especially for organizations planning to use real-world evidence in regulatory submissions. Second, interoperability frameworks should prioritize security and accessibility. SMART on FHIR protocols facilitate secure application integration, while FAIR data principles ensure that research data is findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable. These frameworks serve as guardrails, guaranteeing that data flows safely and efficiently between systems. Third, technical infrastructure must facilitate real-time data exchange. Cloud-native platforms and API-first architectures allow for scalable data processing, while blockchain-based audit trails ensure data provenance. This infrastructure serves as the backbone of successful integration efforts.

For organizations beginning this journey, a phased approach is most effective:

Start with a comprehensive assessment of current standards implementation

Identify gaps in relation to 2025 requirements

Develop a prioritized roadmap for adoption

Invest in technology and staff training support

Implement ongoing monitoring and improvement processes

Looking ahead, successful organizations will focus on developing capabilities that facilitate:

Automated mapping between healthcare and research standards

Real-time data quality validation

Seamless integration between research and care systems

Efficient cross-organizational collaboration

Achieving the goals of 2025 requires strategic investments in these standards and initiatives. Organizations that prioritize this integration now will strengthen their position for participating in the future of clinical research and healthcare delivery.

What data access and privacy frameworks should drug developers implement to balance patient data ownership rights with research requirements?

In the modern era of drug development, pharmaceutical companies encounter a significant challenge: how to safeguard patient privacy while facilitating essential medical research. The solution involves establishing intelligent, balanced frameworks that benefit patients and scientific progress.

Consider contemporary data privacy frameworks like an advanced safety deposit box system. Patients possess their personal health data, similar to items within a safety deposit box, but they can provide researchers with limited access to foster medical advancements. This method is transforming the way drug developers manage sensitive health information.

Three essential elements contribute to the success of these frameworks:

First, dynamic consent management gives patients real control over their data. Unlike traditional one-time consent forms, modern systems allow patients to update their preferences over time. Imagine a smartphone app where patients can easily view how their data is being used and adjust their sharing preferences with a few taps. This transparency builds trust and encourages participation in research. Second, privacy-preserving technologies serve as a protective shield. New methods enable researchers to analyze data patterns without accessing individual patient records—akin to appreciating the forest while keeping the individual trees private. For example, federated learning allows researchers to train AI models across multiple hospitals without patient data leaving their secure local systems. Third, clear governance structures ensure accountability. This includes: Simple rules for data access

Regular privacy assessments

Accurate documentation of data usage

Transparent communication with patients

Independent oversight committees

Recent technological advances have made it easier to maintain privacy while conducting sophisticated research. These innovations include:

Advanced encryption that enables the analysis of encrypted data

AI-generated synthetic data for testing

Privacy-focused analytical tools

For patients, these frameworks offer peace of mind, knowing their personal information remains protected while contributing to medical advances. For researchers, they provide clear guidelines for accessing and using data responsibly, speeding up the drug development process. The future of drug development depends on finding this balance between privacy and progress. Organizations that embrace these modern frameworks now will be better positioned to develop life-saving treatments while maintaining the patients’ trust.

What quantifiable metrics best evaluate ROI for investments in continuous data capture and RWD integration technologies?

The business value of investing in various data capture and RWD systems is often in question. How can we determine if it’s worth it?

Different approaches exist to address this question, each designed for a particular audience. When interacting with senior leaders at a biopharma company, it’s essential to emphasize the key strategic advantages: faster drug development, more effective study designs, enhanced real-world evidence, and a fortified market position. While evaluating the ROI for these technologies might seem daunting, breaking it down into clear, measurable metrics can simplify the task.

These measurements tend to fit into three major categories:

First, operational efficiency indicates how well systems streamline daily tasks. For instance, a leading pharmaceutical company recently reported that its new data integration platform reduced data processing time by nearly half and cut manual data entry by 60%. These enhancements lead directly to cost savings and quicker study completion times. Secondly, quality and compliance metrics reveal the effectiveness of systems in preserving data integrity and adhering to regulatory standards. Consider this as the technology’s immune system—its efficiency in preventing errors and sustaining optimal performance. Some examples of measures to consider (with fictitious percentages): 40-60% reduction in data errors

50% quicker issue resolution

30-40% less time dedicated to audit preparations

25-35% enhancement in data completeness Lastly, metrics reflecting business impact showcase the advantages for the bottom line. They indicate long-term health outcomes and illustrate how the investment improves overall organizational performance. Examples can include: Studies started 20-30% faster

Reduced cost per patient by 15-25%

Regulatory submissions accelerated by 20-30%

Patient retention improved by 15-25%

Effectively measuring ROI requires ongoing monitoring and regular evaluations. Organizations should select metrics that align with their specific goals, balancing immediate efficiency with long-term strategic value. It’s essential to remember that true value often goes beyond mere financial figures. While cost reductions are significant, the real benefits arise from improved decision-making, better patient outcomes, and quicker development of new therapies. By tracking relevant metrics, organizations can showcase the full value of their technological investments and inform future resource allocation decisions.

How should drug development teams prepare for evolving regulatory requirements in embedded clinical trials while maintaining compliance?

When constructing a house, the best home developers aim not only to comply with current building codes but also to have the ability to adapt to future changes. This mirrors the challenge faced by drug developers involved in embedded clinical trials: balancing adherence to existing regulations with foresight toward future needs. The objective extends beyond compliance with today’s standards; it focuses on creating a program that can seamlessly evolve as requirements shift. Organizations that prioritize flexible methodologies now will find it easier to navigate future adjustments while working to ensure trials remain safe and effective. By incorporating adaptability today, these organizations can address new demands while upholding the rigorous standards expected by patients and regulators.

Innovative organizations are taking a three-pronged approach to navigate the evolving landscape of clinical trial regulations. Their success offers valuable lessons for the broader industry.

First, they are creating what can be termed a “flexible foundation” for their clinical operations. The FDA’s most recent guidance on digital health technologies highlights the necessity for adaptability. Forward-thinking companies are implementing easily updatable digital documentation systems and flexible quality management processes that can evolve alongside changing requirements. They are also adopting monitoring methods that effectively operate both on-site and remotely, all while maintaining comprehensive oversight of all trial activities. The COVID-19 pandemic demonstrated the value of this approach – organizations with adaptable systems quickly transitioned to remote monitoring and virtual visits, while those with inflexible processes found it difficult to adapt.

Technology is the second pillar of their strategy. Leading organizations are investing in modular systems that can evolve with regulatory requirements. This encompasses cloud-based platforms that update automatically, data systems that seamlessly integrate new features, and advanced compliance tools that offer real-time monitoring and issue detection. These technological solutions provide a foundation for maintaining compliance while facilitating swift adaptation to new requirements.

The third crucial element centers on people and processes. Even the most advanced technology requires skilled professionals to operate effectively. Forward-thinking organizations build dedicated teams to monitor regulatory changes, implement ongoing training programs to keep staff updated, and establish clear procedures for executing updates. They are also investing in strong relationships with regulatory agencies to stay ahead of emerging requirements.

As they look to the future, successful organizations are focusing on understanding regulatory trends, developing staff expertise, and creating efficient processes to implement changes. This comprehensive approach can help to ensure they maintain compliance today while being prepared for tomorrow’s requirements.

0.title: Oracle Exadata X11M Delivers Extreme Performance, Increased Efficiency, and Improved Energy Savings for Data and AI Workloads
0.snippet: Oracle today introduced Oracle Exadata X11M, the latest generation of the Oracle Exadata platform. Starting at the same price as the previous generation,...
0.content:
Oracle today introduced Oracle Exadata X11M, the latest generation of the Oracle Exadata platform. Starting at the same price as the previous generation, Exadata X11M delivers significant performance improvements across AI, analytics, and online transaction processing (OLTP). Combining intelligent power management with the ability to run mission-critical workloads faster and on fewer systems helps customers achieve their energy efficiency and sustainability goals. In addition, the same capabilities are available across public cloud, multicloud, and on-premises environments, giving customers flexibility to deploy and run their Oracle Database workloads wherever they need without any application changes.

“With Oracle Exadata X11M, we continue to provide customers with extreme scale, performance, business value, and the choice and flexibility to deploy wherever they need—from public cloud to multicloud to on-premises. In fact, every leading cloud will be running Exadata X11M, including OCI, AWS, Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure,” said Kothanda Umamageswaran, senior vice president, Exadata and Scale-Out Technologies, Oracle. “Whether upgrading an existing system or deploying new applications on Exadata X11M, customers benefit from new levels of price performance, consolidation, and efficiency with resulting savings in hardware, power and cooling, and data center space.”

Significant value with more performance at the same price

Optimized for the latest generation AMD EPYC™ processors, Exadata X11M enables orders of magnitude higher performance than competitive database systems. Exadata X11M’s performance increased across all workloads, with much faster vector search for AI, much faster IOPS and shorter latencies for transaction processing, and much faster data scans and query throughput for analytics. With the ability to scan data in both flash and Exadata RDMA Memory (XRMEM), Exadata X11M can achieve extraordinary analytics throughput. These enhancements are available at the same price as the previous generation Exadata X10M, enabling customers to reduce costs by doing more work on the same size platform.

Exadata X11M performance improvements compared to X10M platform include:

AI Vector Search: Up to 55 percent faster persistent vector index (IVF) searches with transparent offloading to intelligent Exadata storage. In addition, in-memory vector index queries (HNSW) are up to 43 percent faster. New software optimizations available across all Exadata platforms provide even faster AI search with 4.7X more data filtering in storage servers and 32X faster queries when searching binary vectors. This enables customers to run sophisticated vector searches faster in combination with more private business data and enhance the accuracy and reliability of generative AI models, while lowering overall costs.

Up to 55 percent faster persistent vector index (IVF) searches with transparent offloading to intelligent Exadata storage. In addition, in-memory vector index queries (HNSW) are up to 43 percent faster. New software optimizations available across all Exadata platforms provide even faster AI search with 4.7X more data filtering in storage servers and 32X faster queries when searching binary vectors. This enables customers to run sophisticated vector searches faster in combination with more private business data and enhance the accuracy and reliability of generative AI models, while lowering overall costs. OLTP: Up to 25 percent faster serial transaction processing, up to 25 percent greater concurrent transaction throughput, and up to 21 percent lower SQL 8K I/O read latency—now only 14us. This enables customers to do more and spend less by running more transactions faster with a smaller database system footprint.

Up to 25 percent faster serial transaction processing, up to 25 percent greater concurrent transaction throughput, and up to 21 percent lower SQL 8K I/O read latency—now only 14us. This enables customers to do more and spend less by running more transactions faster with a smaller database system footprint. Analytics: Up to 25 percent faster analytic query processing, up to 2.2X faster analytic I/O on storage servers, and an increase of up to 500GB/sec Database In-Memory Scan. When combined with other Exadata innovations, this enables customers to run real-time analytics on transactional data and more rapidly scan terabyte to petabyte data warehouses to gain critical business insights.

Improved energy efficiency and sustainability

Exadata X11M also helps customers significantly reduce power and costs in four different ways. First, Exadata X11M’s high performance enables customers to run their portfolio of database workloads on fewer systems, helping save on infrastructure, power and cooling, and data center space. Second, Exadata X11M improves utilization efficiency by enabling more workloads to be consolidated on smaller systems. Third, intelligent power management is built directly into Exadata X11M, helping customers address energy efficiency and sustainability goals by letting them turn off unneeded CPU cores, cap power consumption, and optimize power utilization during periods of low usage. Finally, customers can benefit from built-in automation through Oracle Autonomous Database, which helps eliminate manual database management tasks and human error.

More deployment flexibility for data and AI workloads

Exadata X11M can be deployed on-premises, or with Exadata Database Service and Autonomous Database on Exadata Cloud@Customer, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI), and multicloud environments. Customers have access to the same Oracle Database and the same capabilities running on the same Exadata architecture in all these environments. Oracle Database is 100-percent compatible across deployments enabling customers to run their workloads wherever they need without any application changes.

In multicloud deployments, Oracle Database will run on Exadata X11M in OCI, AWS, Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure data centers. With this option, customers have access to all Oracle Database capabilities, including Oracle Real Application Clusters, which uniquely enables scaling and high availability during planned and unplanned downtime. In addition, customers can combine their applications, AI models, or analytics tools in AWS, Google Cloud, or Microsoft Azure with their data in Oracle databases supported by a low-latency network connection.

Customer and Analyst Quotes

“We have Exadata Database Machine as well as Exadata Cloud@Customer deployed in our Swisscom data centers,” said Moritz Werning, product manager, Swisscom Ltd. “It’s great news that Oracle Exadata X11M is available at the same time in all deployment options, including multicloud deployment. We look forward to gaining all the performance and price performance benefits as well as the efficiencies that Exadata X11M delivers. Higher efficiency can help us to achieve our energy and sustainability goals while continuously improving our customer service.”

“It’s never been more clear than today that Exadata is the industry standard platform to run Oracle Database,” said Ron Westfall, research director, The Futurum Group. “Whether its powering Oracle Database 23ai in hyperscalers such as AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud—or outperforming on-premises infrastructure from any major vendor out there—the latest Exadata X11M allows organizations to decide where they want to gain the best performance for their Oracle Database workloads. And for everything from extreme vector processing to stock exchange-level transactions. Exadata X11M is clearly the gold standard by which all other platforms that try to run Oracle Database are measured.”

Additional Resources

1.title: The IBM-Oracle-Accelalpha partnership poised for the era of business transformation
1.snippet: The recent partnership between IBM and Accelalpha, finalized with IBM's acquisition of the Oracle-services provider, aims to enhance client success through...
1.content:
In a recent ERP Today roundtable discussion, industry leaders from IBM, Oracle, and Accelalpha unveiled the core vision of their newly formed partnership: delivering client success through enhanced business vitality.

Corinne Koppel, Global Oracle Practice Leader at IBM, emphasized the importance of helping businesses thrive in both stable and uncertain times. The collaborative intent is not only to improve client relationships but also to build a robust foundation for enterprise success, she said about IBM’s acquisition of Oracle-services provider Accelalpha that was finalized in Q4 2024.

The acquisition marks a significant milestone in IBM’s growth trajectory as it adds crucial finance and supply chain capabilities to its offerings. Moreover, the company has grown its geographic reach with Accelalpha’s team of consultants across North America, Europe, Asia, the Middle East and South America, onboarding at IBM on the completion of the deal.

Explore related questions Ask ERP Today what is this?

Koppel noted, “We’re focused on four key geographies for growth: the Americas, the UK & Ireland, and Japan. Now, with Accelalpha, we’re able to enhance that reach across all these regions while adding focus to our key markets.”

Paul Pessutti, Senior Vice President at Oracle, expressed his optimism about the acquisition, describing it as “the coming together of two exceptional firms where we already have strong, deep relationships and trust built up within Oracle and with our clients.”

This sentiment resonated with Dan Haller, Group Vice President at Oracle, who observed that customers, especially in the supply chain space, who need enterprise transformations, could really benefit from the partnership. “[We have] some strong functional supply chain capabilities, and IBM is well known as a global systems invitation partner that works with customers strategically in the industries it is focused on,” he said.

The collaboration between Accelalpha and IBM is viewed as a “logical marriage” by Joe Spear, Partner at Accelalpha.

The combined capabilities of both organizations promise to deliver comprehensive solutions that address core business challenges globally. Spear noted that Accelalpha excels in Oracle implementations covering core ERP, Enterprise Performance Management (EPM), Supply Chain Management (SCM), logistics, and customer experience suites—components essential for addressing fundamental business issues.

With IBM’s distinguished managed services portfolio, both companies are poised to deliver end-to-end support for clients, enhancing the client experience post-implementation.

Kevin Beyer, Managing Partner at Accelalpha, expressed enthusiasm about integrating this service with Accelalpha’s offerings for continuous support and software lifecycle management. “IBM is ranked as a global leader in the managed service offering, and we’re able to bring that to our customers now,” he said.

An exciting frontier of this partnership is the integration of Generative AI (GenAI). Teams from all three organizations are eager to collaborate and leverage AI capabilities to enhance business processes.

Chacko Thomas, Americas Oracle Practice Leader at IBM, illustrated practical applications where intelligent workflows can rapidly assess business processes and provide swift ROI assessments.

As the wheels of this partnership continue to turn, the collaboration between IBM, Oracle, and Accelalpha promises to be transformative for enterprises seeking innovative solutions and strategies.

Thomas concluded: “We’ve been very clear about this right from our announcement of the acquisition. We are committed to keeping the Oracle channels whole. We have committed to keeping the business model, which includes pricing and other things. In fact, Accelalpha will now have access to all of IBM’s enterprise bands, so it will only get better in terms of scale and depth.”

3.title: Ireckonu's CORE Middleware and Customer Data Platform Now Available on Oracle Cloud Marketplace
3.snippet: AMSTERDAM, THE NETHERLANDS – Ireckonu, a leading provider of hospitality digital solutions, and a member of Oracle PartnerNetwork (OPN), today announced...
3.content:
AMSTERDAM, THE NETHERLANDS – Ireckonu, a leading provider of hospitality digital solutions, and a member of Oracle PartnerNetwork (OPN), today announced Ireckonu CORE Middleware and Customer Data Platform (CDP) is available on Oracle Cloud Marketplace and can be deployed on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) and integrated with OPERA Cloud via the Oracle Hospitality Integration Platform (OHIP). Oracle Cloud Marketplace is a centralized repository of enterprise applications offered by Oracle and Oracle partners.

The Ireckonu CORE Middleware and Customer Data Platform enables hotel chains to connect technology systems with two-way, real-time integrations. Designed for the complexities of the hospitality industry, Ireckonu connects hospitality software, such as booking engines and reservation systems, with OPERA Cloud. This integration removes duplicate profiles and ensures guest data remains clean and consistent across all tools.

Oracle Cloud Marketplace is a one-stop shop for Oracle customers seeking trusted business applications and services offering unique solutions, including ones that extend Oracle Fusion Cloud Applications.

OCI is a deep and broad platform of cloud infrastructure services that enables customers to build and run a wide range of applications in a scalable, secure, highly available, and high-performance environment. From application development and business analytics to data management, integration, security, AI, and infrastructure services including Kubernetes and VMware, OCI delivers comprehensive security, performance, and cost savings. In addition, with multicloud, hybrid cloud, public cloud, and dedicated cloud options, OCI’s distributed cloud offers customers the benefits of cloud with greater control over data residency, locality, and authority, even across multiple clouds. As a result, customers can bring enterprise workloads to the cloud quickly and efficiently while addressing the strictest regulatory compliance requirements.

“Ireckonu’s availability on Oracle Cloud Marketplace allows us to easily collaborate with leading hotel chains that use the OPERA Cloud as their PMS provider,” said Jan Jaap van Roon, CEO of Ireckonu. “Ireckonu’s participation in Oracle Cloud Marketplace further extends our commitment to the Oracle community and enables customers to easily reap the benefits of our CORE Middleware and Customer Data Platform. We look forward to leveraging the power of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure to help us achieve our business goals.”

By integrating with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure and Oracle Hospitality Integration Platform, Ireckonu enables hotel chains to connect their technology ecosystems with two-way, real-time integrations. This ensures that guest data remains clean and consistent across all tools, empowering hotels to deliver personalized guest experiences. Ireckonu’s participation in Oracle Cloud Marketplace further extends their commitment to the Oracle community and enables customers to experience the benefits of Ireckonu.

About Ireckonu

Founded in 2014, Ireckonu is a leading Dutch company revolutionizing the hospitality industry through innovative digital solutions. With a global team of over 60 professionals, Ireckonu specializes in cutting-edge Software as a Service (SaaS) products and services. Seamlessly integrating Middleware expertise with a state-of-the-art Customer Data Platform, Ireckonu empowers hotels with a unified, data-driven approach, trusted by renowned brands such as Okura, CitizenM, Hard Rock Hotels, and more. Ireckonu stands at the forefront of shaping the future of hospitality.

Visit the Ireckonu website to discover more: www.ireckonu.com.

About Oracle PartnerNetwork

Oracle PartnerNetwork (OPN) is Oracle’s partner program designed to enable partners to accelerate the transition to cloud and drive superior customer business outcomes. The OPN program allows partners to engage with Oracle through track(s) aligned to how they go to market: Cloud Build for partners that provide products or services built on or integrated with Oracle Cloud; Cloud Sell for partners that resell Oracle Cloud technology; Cloud Service for partners that implement, deploy and manage Oracle Cloud Services; Industry Healthcare for partners that provide commercially available products and/or services built with Oracle Cloud and Oracle Health technologies; and License & Hardware for partners that build, service or sell Oracle software licenses or hardware products. Customers can expedite their business objectives with OPN partners who have achieved Expertise in a product family or cloud service. To learn more visit: http://www.oracle.com/partnernetwork.

Trademark

Oracle, Java, MySQL and NetSuite are registered trademarks of Oracle Corporation. NetSuite was the first cloud company—ushering in the new era of cloud computing.

John Seaton

Chief Operating Office

4.title: CEO Outlook 2025: Safra Catz on How Oracle Transforms Healthcare with Cloud Integration
4.snippet: CEO Safra Catz explains Oracle's vision for making healthcare more efficient by automating connections and reducing the burden on hospitals with cloud-based...
4.content:
In this exclusive moment from the Cloud Wars Top 10 CEO Outlook 2025 series, CEO Safra Catz explains how end-to-end offerings in healthcare, powered by cloud capabilities and seamless integration, are key to improving efficiency and reducing waste in the industry.

Highlights

00:17 — If you’re not supporting healthcare processes end-to-end, that means connections all have to be managed at the customer site, which means every single one has to reinvent the wheel, figure it out, and then maintain all those connections. That’s not right in the era of the cloud, when you get new capabilities every 90 days.

Ask Cloud Wars AI Agent about this analysis

01:08 — Doctors, nurses, and radiologists often aren’t employees of the hospital. They’re employees of a group that operates in the hospital. We wrote that into our HCM systems. In all of these different things — financials, billing, revenue management. It’s not fair to ask hospitals to waste their resources stitching this stuff together when we do it once.

02:06 — [Oracle Chairman Larry Ellison] said it best: “We’re doing this because we can, but we can’t do it alone.” That means partnering with our customers, partnering with other capabilities that come from other companies, and making sure we are delivering an experience for our customers and for the patients, doctors, and administrators, where they can do more and spend less doing it.

AI Agent & Copilot Summit NA is an AI-first event to define opportunities, impact, and outcomes with Microsoft Copilot and agents for mid-market and enterprise companies. It takes place March 17-19 in San Diego, CA. Register now to attend.

6.title: CISA warns of critical Oracle, Mitel flaws exploited in attacks
6.snippet: CISA has warned U.S. federal agencies to secure their systems against critical vulnerabilities in Oracle WebLogic Server and Mitel MiCollab systems that are...
6.content:
CISA has warned U.S. federal agencies to secure their systems against critical vulnerabilities in Oracle WebLogic Server and Mitel MiCollab systems that are actively exploited in attacks.

The cybersecurity agency added a critical path traversal vulnerability (CVE-2024-41713) found in the NuPoint Unified Messaging (NPM) component Mitel's MiCollab unified communications platform to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog.

This security bug allows attackers to perform unauthorized administrative actions and access user and network information.

"A successful exploit of this vulnerability could allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access, with potential impacts to the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the system. This vulnerability is exploitable without authentication," MiCollab explains.

"If the vulnerability is successfully exploited, an attacker could gain unauthenticated access to provisioning information including non-sensitive user and network information and perform unauthorized administrative actions on the MiCollab Server."

The critical Oracle WebLogic Server flaw tracked as CVE-2020-2883 and patched four years ago in April 2020 enables unauthenticated attackers to take unpatched servers remotely.

The U.S. cybersecurity agency also warned of a second Mitel MiCollab path traversal vulnerability (CVE-2024-55550), enabling authenticated attackers with admin privileges to read arbitrary files on vulnerable servers. However, the impact is limited because successful exploitation doesn't allow privilege escalation, and accessible files don't contain sensitive system information.

Today, CISA added all three vulnerabilities to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog, tagging them as actively exploited. As mandated by the Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01 issued in November 2021, Federal Civilian Executive Branch (FCEB) agencies must secure their networks within three weeks by January 28.

"These types of vulnerabilities are frequent attack vectors for malicious cyber actors and pose significant risks to the federal enterprise," CISA said on Tuesday.

While the KEV catalog focuses on alerting U.S. federal agencies regarding vulnerabilities that should be patched as soon as possible, all organizations are advised to prioritize mitigating these security flaws to block ongoing attacks.

7.title: Divination: Call of the Morrigan oracle deck.
7.snippet: Which is honestly to be expected; the Morrigan is, among other things, a goddess of war. The advice and suggested actions are more challenging than comforting.
7.content:
Back in the early 90s I worked at a small New Age book & gift shop in San Diego. Among our most popular items were oracle decks. Which are cards, but not the same thing as tarot. We sold a lot of oracle decks.

Our best-selling oracle decks fell into three categories. First, the "messages from the angels" (pretty young women with big fluffy wings and long floaty dresses). Second, the "messages from the fairies" (pretty young women with butterfly wings and short floaty dresses). Third, animal totem/spirit decks. Which often had a faux Native American vibe (cultural appropriation wasn't an issue for some authors). The advice being offered reminded me of fortune cookies.

I decided that I didn't like oracle decks.

I've recently had to revise my opinion somewhat.

I held to that opinion for over thirty years. Until someone recently shared a picture online, of a bookcase in a Barnes & Noble. It was packed with divination decks of all kinds, and right in the middle was an oracle deck that I couldn't dismiss out of hand.

One of the authors also wrote the book at right.

The title and cover art caught my eye first. Seeing the name of one of my favorite Pagan authors clinched the deal for me. This deck and book are the work of three women- writers Stephanie Woodfield and Karen Storminger, and artist Naomi Cornock. They're all priestesses of the Morrigan.

The book is illustrated with black & white versions of the cards.

At 205 pages the guidebook is indeed a book, not a pamphlet. There are entries for each card; these go well beyond a basic explanation of the pictures. There are discussions of the images and symbols contained in each card, of the ancient sources they are drawn from (with citations), their historic meanings and their relevance to modern readers.

Each card entry includes suggestions for meditations and spells; the cards are intended for use as altar images and in spellwork. The suggested spells are fairly simple and most use items we usually have on hand like candles, paper, salt, and water. There's a chapter on oracle spreads, another on spells and rituals, and a pronunciation guide for possibly unfamiliar Irish words. The suggested reading list includes titles by other authors (including Morgan Daimler, another of my favorites) and online resources.

Left, the reverse of each card. Right, an illustration I especially like.

The deck consists of forty-five cards, divided into five suits- Guises of the Morrigan, Otherworldly Guides, Spirits of the Land, Outer Worlds, and Inner Worlds. The cards themselves are beautifully printed in rich colors on nice, heavy cardstock with a smooth low-gloss finish.

The Guises of the Morrigan suit explores the many faces and facets of this complex and surprising goddess; some are individual goddesses, others are archetypes.

From Guises of the Morrigan suit- 1 Badb, 6 Shapeshifter, 9 Lady of Sovereignty.

Otherworldly Guides presents deities, heroes, and magical treasures drawn from the lore of Irish deities and faery folk.

From Otherworldly Guides suit- 13 Sword of Nuada, 12 Lia Fail, 14 Cauldron of the Dagda.

The Spirits of the Land suit represents sacred places throughout Ireland. While mentioned in Irish mythology as the sites of supernatural events, each is also a place that actually exists.

From Spirits of the Land suit- 20 Well of Slaine, 21 Oweynagat, 19 Paps of Anu.

The Outer Worlds suit represents forces and things existing in the world around us which are outside of our control.

From Outer Worlds suit- 30 Battle, 34 Fate, 32 Peace.

The Inner Worlds suit represents our inner life and experiences. These are explored through the lens of ancient myths.

From Inner Worlds suit- 39 Forgiveness, 40 Consequences, 43 Oath.

I'm enjoying exploring this deck; I think it could be a good fit for others who worship and work with Celtic/Irish deities. Persons who are interested in goddess religion and magic, and are looking to expand their practice to include Celtic goddesses might also like it. Also those with an interest in what I can only describe as badass feminine archetypes.

I find the text well-written and insightful, the artwork beautiful and powerful; it is, while not overly graphic, somewhat gruesome at times. Which is honestly to be expected; the Morrigan is, among other things, a goddess of war. The advice and suggested actions are more challenging than comforting. Which makes this oracle deck a good choice for me.

Call of the Morrigan Oracle: A 45-Card Deck & Guidebook. Copyright 2024, by Stephanie Woodfield, Karen Storminger, and Naomi Cornock. Llewellyn Publications. ISBN: 978-0-7387-7768-9. $29.99. Available from Barnes & Noble and Amazon.

•••••••

Thank you for reading. This is an open thread, all topics are welcome.

8.title: Oracle (NYSE:ORCL) Hasn't Managed To Accelerate Its Returns
8.snippet: Finding a business that has the potential to grow substantially is not easy, but it is possible if we look at a few key...
8.content:
Finding a business that has the potential to grow substantially is not easy, but it is possible if we look at a few key financial metrics. In a perfect world, we'd like to see a company investing more capital into its business and ideally the returns earned from that capital are also increasing. Put simply, these types of businesses are compounding machines, meaning they are continually reinvesting their earnings at ever-higher rates of return. That's why when we briefly looked at Oracle's (NYSE:ORCL) ROCE trend, we were pretty happy with what we saw.

Return On Capital Employed (ROCE): What Is It?

For those that aren't sure what ROCE is, it measures the amount of pre-tax profits a company can generate from the capital employed in its business. To calculate this metric for Oracle, this is the formula:

Return on Capital Employed = Earnings Before Interest and Tax (EBIT) ÷ (Total Assets - Current Liabilities)

0.14 = US$17b ÷ (US$148b - US$29b) (Based on the trailing twelve months to November 2024).

So, Oracle has an ROCE of 14%. In absolute terms, that's a satisfactory return, but compared to the Software industry average of 8.2% it's much better.

See our latest analysis for Oracle

NYSE:ORCL Return on Capital Employed January 7th 2025

Above you can see how the current ROCE for Oracle compares to its prior returns on capital, but there's only so much you can tell from the past. If you're interested, you can view the analysts predictions in our free analyst report for Oracle .

What Can We Tell From Oracle's ROCE Trend?

While the returns on capital are good, they haven't moved much. The company has consistently earned 14% for the last five years, and the capital employed within the business has risen 42% in that time. 14% is a pretty standard return, and it provides some comfort knowing that Oracle has consistently earned this amount. Over long periods of time, returns like these might not be too exciting, but with consistency they can pay off in terms of share price returns.

The Bottom Line On Oracle's ROCE

To sum it up, Oracle has simply been reinvesting capital steadily, at those decent rates of return. And the stock has done incredibly well with a 226% return over the last five years, so long term investors are no doubt ecstatic with that result. So even though the stock might be more "expensive" than it was before, we think the strong fundamentals warrant this stock for further research.

If you want to continue researching Oracle, you might be interested to know about the 1 warning sign that our analysis has discovered.

9.title: CISA adds 2020 Oracle vulnerability to KEV: We hope you...
9.snippet: Five years after a critical Oracle WebLogic server bug was first reported exploited, CISA has added CVE-2020-2883 to its KEV catalogue.
9.content:
Better late than never: Five long years after a critical Oracle WebLogic server bug was first reported exploited in the wild, CISA has added CVE-2020-2883 to its known exploited vulnerabilities (KEV) catalogue.

CISA itself highlighted exploitation in 2020 and its addition to KEV in 2025 is likely to be some “dang-we-forgot-to-add-this-one” housekeeping, rather than indication of particularly renewed exploitation. (If you didn’t patch your servers for 60 months, welcome to a world of hurt anyhow.)

CVE-2020-2883 was reported by Bui Duong of Viettel Cyber Security via the ZDI. The underlying bug is in Oracle’s “Coherence” library and any application with the Coherence library in its code path where there is a path to deserialization is also vulnerable, researchers warned at the time.

Also new to KEV this week are CVE-2024-41713 (a Mitel MiCollab path traversal bug) and CVE-2024-55550 (ditto). Both have been known to be exploited in the wild for at least a month, so those (hopefully a limited number of people) relying on CVEs being added to KEV to enforce patching, are firmly shutting the stable door after the horse has not only bolted but been found with a broken leg and turned into dogfood.

With regard to the Mitel vulnerabilities, as attack surface specialist WatchTowr noted in December: “VoIP platforms, which handle telephone calls for an organization, are a really juicy target for an APT. Imagine being able to listen in on the phone calls of your target, as they're happening - or even to interfere with them and block them at will! It's a very powerful thing to be able to do, and a godsend for an outcome-motivated attacker.

A tear-down of the Mitel platform revealed some dubious product development decisions in the underlying code and what looks like a juicy attack surface, so… stay up to speed with ongoing patching and advisories from your VoIP providers, even if KEV is late to the party. ...

0.title: Grupo Bimbo uses Oracle Fusion Applications to run its business
0.snippet: Grupo Bimbo kneads Oracle Fusion Cloud apps into its growth strategy. The world's largest baking company is moving beyond the “realm of science fiction” with...
0.content:
AI applications

Grupo Bimbo’s new data strategy is also allowing it to make greater use of emerging technologies, such as AI and virtual reality.

The company plans to use AI’s image recognition capabilities to identify defective goods on its production lines in real time. “Now we have a more proactive way of determining whether an oven is behaving in a different way and maybe stop it there, instead of losing an entire production,” Bustos says.

The Mexico City–based company is also working to improve driver safety through more immersive AI-driven virtual reality training. “We can simulate a lot of different conditions—rain, snow, hay, cows crossing the street—and ensure that our drivers know what to do in each circumstance,” he says.

Grupo Bimbo also plans to use the AI and analytics capabilities of Fusion Data Intelligence to better understand consumer demand patterns and improve sales forecasting. Data is now more accessible to company users, including those who work at the Connection Center, which could lead to “new ways of operating or even creating new revenue streams out of the data we are generating,” Bustos says.

None of this analysis, however, would have been possible if Grupo Bimbo hadn’t decided to use Oracle Fusion Cloud globally and to standardize data formats for its entire enterprise, he says.

“The AI revolution came at a very good moment,” Bustos says, “because now we do have the data to start leveraging and exploiting that technology more than we did in the past.”

1.title: Watch for Oracle JD Edwards EnterpriseOne Release 25 Customer Go-Lives in H1
1.snippet: Oracle JD Edwards announced the release of EnterpriseOne Release 25 in Q4 2024, featuring enhancements that improve business process automation and...
1.content:
Oracle JD Edwards (JDE) announced the availability of EnterpriseOne Release 25 in Q4 2024, bringing to market enhancements that automate, optimize, and transform business processes across areas such as finance, sales and warehouse management and represents Oracle’s continued investment in the JDE solution portfolio. So we will see the first wave of customers deploying Release 25 in the first half of 2025.

Oracle acquired JD Edwards as part of its acquisition of PeopleSoft in January 2005, and the JDE suite serves a diverse customer base of over 17,000 companies across various industries and regions. The customer base includes organizations of varying sizes, from mid-sized enterprises to large corporations. Notable companies using JD Edwards include Chevron, Charter Communications, and Hindustan Petroleum Corporation. Industries such as manufacturing, distribution, construction, and consumer goods frequently adopt JD Edwards to manage complex operational needs. The software’s modular architecture and comprehensive functionalities make it a preferred choice for organizations seeking integrated solutions for finance, human resources, supply chain, and customer relationship management.

Key feature updates in Release 25 include the following:

Explore related questions Ask ERP Today what is this?

Ability to Assign Delinquency Fees to the Business Unit of Invoice: The Credit Analysis Refresh program has been enhanced with a new processing option. This enhancement enables users to choose a business unit (BU) either invoice BU or the BU specified in the customer’s Address Book record for accounting delinquency fees.

Increased Range of Account IDs: This feature increases the range of Account IDs by allowing alphanumeric account IDs. This feature enables large businesses to maintain longer history and accounts from acquisitions and mergers can be included with ease.

Enterprise Automation: Order to Cash Integrated with Warehouse (EnterpriseOne Page): This new functionality enables you to create a process flow that uses your organization’s real-time data to provide guidance for controlling and coordinating the flow and sequence of tasks that help to achieve overall goals and objectives as efficiently as possible. This enhancement also enables visibility to orders at key stages of the order to cash process to help you maximize on-time and accurate order fulfillment and make better use of data to help reveal trouble spots that adversely impact your key performance indicators (KPIs).

Enterprise Automation: Order to Cash Process Model Template: This new functionality enables you to generate a process flow that uses your organization’s real-time data to provide guidance for controlling and coordinating the flow and sequence of tasks that help to achieve overall goals and objectives as efficiently as possible. This enhancement also enables visibility to orders at key stages of the order to cash process to help customers maximize on-time and accurate inventory, and make better use of data to help reveal trouble spots that adversely impact your KPIs.

Enterprise Automation: Procure to Pay Integrated with Warehouse (EnterpriseOne Page): This functionality helps customers to improve procure to pay operations through integrated automation and data it generates. This enhancement provides visibility to warehouse putaway process integrated with the procure to pay process to help customers maximize efficiency and maintain accurate inventory. Three critical KPIs – Putaway cycle time, putaway accuracy and location utilization are provided as new charts.

License Plate Workbench Usability Enhancements: The current updates are aimed at improving the overall user experience and enriching functionality for the License Plate Workbench. New usability capabilities include visibility to date and time information along with the ability to search and filter records by date. The License Plate Workbench application is enhanced by providing access to new applications that enable you to efficiently manage license plate information for loose items.

Sustainability Foundation and Scope 1 Stationary Emissions: The JD Edwards Sustainability Framework simplifies and streamlines the collection of environmental data. This feature provides the ability to collect the fuel usage from stationary combustion sources (Scope 1), directly from JD Edwards transactions, including Voucher Match and Standard Voucher applications. Additionally, this framework enables customers to directly input the stationary combustion data into a centralized repository known as the Sustainability Activity Ledger. The JD Edwards Sustainability Framework, by offering an optimized solution to collect the data and with the option of leveraging external carbon calculation and reporting tools, helps organizations with their environmental goals and provides a roadmap for more sustainable business practices.

What this means for ERP Insiders

Why should JDE customers move to Release 25? As of January 2025, the majority of JD Edwards customers are utilizing EnterpriseOne Release 9.2, which was initially launched in October 2015. Oracle has continued to enhance this release with subsequent updates, including Release 23, Release 24, and the most recent Release 25. Approximately 86% of the JD Edwards customer base has adopted version 9.2, and Oracle has announced support for JD Edwards products through at least 2035, providing customers with a clear roadmap for future planning and upgrades. JDE customers stand to gain the following from Release 25:

Enhanced Orchestrator Capabilities: The Orchestrator tool has been improved to automate complex business processes more effectively, featuring better error handling and data validation to reduce manual intervention.

Industry-Specific Functionality: Release 25 offers tailored features for sectors such as manufacturing, construction, and distribution, addressing unique industry challenges. For example, the new Project Status Inquiry (PSI) feature aids construction project managers in tracking progress and improving delivery timelines.

User Experience (UX) Enhancements: The update provides a more intuitive and efficient interface, simplifying daily tasks for users.

Integration with Hybrid Cloud: Release 25 strengthens integration with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) and other cloud services, facilitating hybrid deployment models that combine on-premise stability with cloud flexibility and scalability.

Enterprise Process Modeler: This new tool offers a graphical representation of business processes, enabling organizations to visualize and optimize workflows effectively.

Optimized Full Package Build Performance: Enhancements in this area reduce build times by identifying and compiling only necessary components, improving efficiency during system updates.

Learn from other JDE customers that have taken recent releases. A leading manufacturing firm collaborated with IT Convergence to upgrade to the latest JD Edwards EnterpriseOne release. The project involved eliminating outdated customizations, implementing a disaster recovery plan with a 24-hour turnaround, and enhancing the Electronic Data Interchange (EDI) order process. Post-upgrade, 50% of EDI orders were processed without manual intervention, significantly improving operational efficiency. Granite Properties, a real estate investment and management company, upgraded to JD Edwards EnterpriseOne Release 23/24 to streamline and automate business processes using Orchestrator and other tools. The upgrade facilitated improved efficiency and better results, aligning with their business growth objectives. And Koos Manufacturing, a denim apparel manufacturer, undertook an upgrade to JD Edwards EnterpriseOne Release 23/24 to enhance their business processes. The implementation of Orchestrator and other features enabled them to automate workflows, resulting in increased operational efficiency and a move towards continuous innovation.

When to choose JD Edwards vs. other Oracle ERP offerings.

2.title: CEO Outlook 2025: Oracle’s Safra Catz — Customers All In On Cloud
2.snippet: Highlights from a conversation with Oracle CEO Safra Katz that covers the company's outlook for 2025, cloud adoption, bold business transformations,...
2.content:
Welcome to the Cloud Wars Minute — your daily cloud news and commentary show. Each episode provides insights and perspectives around the “reimagination machine” that is the cloud.

In today’s Cloud Wars Minute, I kick off our CEO Outlook 2025 series with a look at my conversation featuring Oracle CEO Safra Catz, discussing key trends in cloud adoption, bold business transformations, and Oracle’s strategic initiatives.

Highlights

00:01 — One of the big messages from Oracle CEO Safra Catz was that customers in 2025 are going to be all in on the cloud. They know that’s how to modernize, take advantage of all their data, become full participants in the AI revolution, and achieve their business objectives of growth, getting closer to customers, dazzling those customers, and moving into new areas.

01:00 — Catz almost never speaks in public. This is a pretty cool opportunity to see what Safra Catz thinks about a lot of things in this very unscripted conversation. She said the customer is embracing this idea that they need to be bold. They can’t just have the cloud become a replacement for technology they had before without changing what they do.

AI Agent & Copilot Summit NA is an AI-first event to define opportunities, impact, and outcomes with Microsoft Copilot and agents for mid-market and enterprise companies. It takes place March 17-19 in San Diego, CA. Register now to attend.

01:54 — She talked about customers working with technology partners who can help them solve end-to-end processes. She said otherwise, you just end up with fragmented pieces and have different vendors pointing at each other about where the problem lies.

03:14 — Catz said that fragementation is out of whack with the needs of the healthcare field, where hospitals, clinics, and laboratories had to take up that effort to integrate and make it all work together. Customers need complete, end-to-end systems. She talked about the multi-cloud miracle when Oracle signed agreements with Microsoft, Google Cloud, and AWS.

04:01 — We talked about the significance of giving customers more openness and flexibility. For her CTO, whose name happens to be Larry Ellison, Catz assured me that it’s going to be a busy year for him, and talked about some of the fun that Ellison is having in different areas. We have the full-length video that you can watch, and also an article later today.
